DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Maximum Diameter Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Measurement
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the measurement as assessed by a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body (MRI) or a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body (CT) as related to maxium tumor diameter.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to maxium tumor diameter.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant ones exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: the largest possible quantity or degree.:Diameter; the length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle and connecting two points on the circumference.

Concepts.definition: The largest possible quantity or degree.
The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and connecting two points on the circumference.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Measurement
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the measurement as assessed by a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body (MRI) or a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body (CT).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Measurement
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders. :A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis. :Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.

ValueDomain.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form
